intro: Galium asperifolium var. verrucifructum, commonly known as the warty-fruited bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, opposite leaves and small, clustered white flowers. The plant produces distinctive, warty-fruited capsules that are often covered in a dense layer of glandular hairs. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of native plant communities in its habitat.
